awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Cloud Computing Infrastructure for Science and Engineering Research Innovations
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides for the acquisition of the Island Science and Engineering Research Cloud (ISERC). ISERC will support major innovative research at Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi (TAMUCC) and other institutions in South Texas. ISERC is an ideal base to tackle a multitude of research problems of regional, national and global significance by providing high capacity computing resources to empower science and engineering research. ISERC enabled projects include geospatial analytics, coastal resiliency, ecology, genomics, bio-informatics, environmental monitoring, health, geology, water resource management, remote sensing, unmanned systems, agriculture, and climate prediction. This research will have impact on the environmental sustainability, health and economic well-being of coastal communities across the globe. The instrument will be used by approximately 100 researchers comprising faculty, graduate and undergraduate students. It is estimated that, each year, more than 300 students enrolled in STEM related courses would also benefit from it.

ISERC supports heterogeneous computing environments with low-latency, high-bandwidth, high computational power, and storage for large data sets. It provides users with a dynamically scalable, robust, heterogeneous, and virtualized architecture. By allowing confidential and secure execution of guest virtual machines, it ensures the privacy and security of data. The new cloud instrument can handle a wide variety of services simultaneously, including ones for real-time, compute-bound, as well as data intensive applications. Some of the major projects that are poised to commence include: hyper-spatial 3D data streams for coastal resiliency, high throughput phenotyping for agriculture, social media data analytics for security, cloud data migration, seagrass genetics, biomimetic catalysis, climate impact on water resources, genome sequencing, and predicting environmental factors for respiratory diseases. ISERC will propel the academic community's knowledge generation and provide research opportunities that will enable many further follow-up projects, including multi-institutional and cross-disciplinary collaborations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2018, Texas A&M University (TAMUCC) received a $517,657 National Science Foundation (NSF) grant to acquire a cloud computing infrastructure for science and engineering research innovation. With this award, the Island Science and Engineering Research Cloud (ISERC) was set up.

There were several delays caused due to Dell shipping out incompatible hardware. The CPU nodes on the cloud were fully functional by August 2019, although the GPU nodes have functioned since May 2020. It took almost 2 years for the cloud to be fully functional. At this point, most research in research labs came to a standstill or slowed down due to the COVID -19 pandemic. Because of this, the award was extended by a period of 2 more years to finish the research projects.

The ISERC website is fully functional (https://iserc.tamucc.edu/). A lot of information has been posted to the website including documentation of the resources, videos related to working on the cloud, forms for requesting access to the cloud, etc. Many Virtual machines (VMs) based on Linux, windows, and windows server operating systems have been uploaded to the cloud, which researchers, as well as teaching-related courses, use as a starting point. 

Many faculty researchers as well as 26 research students benefited by using the cloud for their research-related projects. A total of approximately 250 students per year used ISERC for their course-related activities since 2020.

Two journal papers and two conference papers were published, and two conference papers and one journal paper under review disseminated the findings of the project. In addition, ISERC was the first cloud at TAMUCC, and it provided the IT personnel to learn about open-stack cloud services that they were not familiar with. In addition, it has enabled several faculty members and lots of students in classes to gain valuable knowledge about how services operate on a cloud.

This project had significant and lasting positive impacts on participants, graduate assistants, faculty, and TAMUCC students at large. This could not have been possible without the generous and necessary support provided by the NSF to acquire ISERC.


Last Modified: 12/06/2022
Modified by: Ajay K Katangur
